sentences: Kara (Hangul: 카라, Japanese: カラ, often stylized as KARA)   was a South Korean pop girl group formed by DSP Media in 2007.
section: N/A

sentences: The group's final lineup was composed of Gyuri, Seungyeon, Hara and Youngji.
section: N/A

sentences: Members Nicole and Jiyoung officially departed from the group in 2014, while Sunghee left in 2008.

sentences: The group originally started off as a quartet and made their debut in March 2007 with their first studio album The First Blooming and its single "Break It" while displaying a strong female image and a mature R&B sound.
section: N/A

sentences: Expectations for the group were big because they were considered as successors to their senior labelmate, Fin.

sentences: K.L.
section: N/A

sentences: However, their debut was not well received by the public and was a commercial failure.

section: N/A

sentences: After their addition, the group also changed their musical style and their image to the "pretty but natural" appeal, releasing their first mini-album, Rock U in July 2008.
section: N/A

sentences: They achieved their first number one song with "Honey" (2009).
section: N/A

sentences: In July 2009, the group released their second studio album, Revolution and spawned the hit single "Mister", whose choreography featured the "butt-dance", that helped increase the group's popularity within East Asia.
section: N/A

sentences: Their follow-up singles including "Lupin" (2010), "Jumping" (2010), "Step" (2011), and "Pandora" (2012) were also successful and helped further establish the group within the Korean music industry.

sentences: The group were ranked at No. 6 and No. 5 in  Gallup Korea in 2009 and 2010 respectively, thus making them the second best girl group in Korea for 2010.

sentences: They were also ranked at No. 4 and 13 in February 2012 and 2013's Forbes Korea Power Celebrity list, respectively.

sentences: After finding national success, the group began to expand their music to Japan by signing to Universal Music Japan's subsidiary label, Universal Sigma in 2010.
section: N/A

sentences: The group's debut was a success as they were dubbed as "Japan's No. 1 Rookie Artist of 2010" by Oricon and also receiving the "New Artist of the Year Award (International)" from the Japan Gold Disc Awards.
section: N/A

sentences: In April 2011, the group achieved their first number one single in Japan with "Jet Coaster Love", making them the first foreign female group since the creation of the Oricon to rank number one in the first week of release and also the first foreign female group in thirty years to do so.
section: N/A

sentences: Overall, the group managed to sell over one million physical singles within two years, making them one of the fastest-selling South Korean acts in Japan.

section: == History == | === 2007: Early beginnings and debut ===

== History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===
== History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The group was scheduled to have their comeback in March 2008 with their second album, however, member Kim Sung-hee suddenly announced that she would be leaving the group and she decided to retire their entertainment industry due to this she first announced her departure from the group due to her parental pressure and hence she failed all of her college exams she made her decision to leave in order to focus on school and education.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: In response, DSP stated that the second album that was recorded would be shelved and replaced by a mini-album to come in May; in addition, two members would join the group.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: Auditions were held, and the two new members were eventually revealed to be Goo Ha-ra and Kang Jiyoung.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The group made their return in the music industry as a quintet on July 24, 2008, with "Rock U" on M! Countdown.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: Their first mini-album titled Rock U was released the next day.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: They made their comeback with the "cute" and "playful" image which was the complete opposite of the group's original image from their debut.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The second season of Kara Self Camera premiered on August 18, 2008, which chronicled how the group was adapting to their two new members.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: On November 29, 2008, DSP released a teaser video for their upcoming single, "Pretty Girl", which received over 40,000 hits within 12 hours.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The full video was released on December 2, 2008, online and was positively received by the public.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The EP, Pretty Girl, was released on December 4, embodying a "fun-party" concept.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The group began promoting their comeback on all major music shows on December 4, 2008, starting with M! Countdown.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: During their first national performance on KBS's Music Bank, member Goo Hara accidentally gasped "ah!"
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: live on air due to slipping on falling confetti, and reportedly cried profusely afterwards.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: The incident became a hot issue to many viewers, but Goo Hara received comfort instead of criticism from the general public.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: Park Gyuri attributed their popularity increase to their "pretty but natural" appeal, while media reports gave credit to the band for finally finding its own identity in the music industry since the group's debut and to older male fans, most notably singer Shin Hae Chul.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===

sentences: Due to their increasingly hectic schedule as their popularity rose, a few of the group's members were taken to the hospital on December 19 after a Music Bank rehearsal for cold symptoms and exhaustion.
section: == History == | === 2008: First line-up changes, Rock U, Pretty Girl and career breakthrough ===
== History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: At the end of January 2009, DSP announced that it would commence voting on January 28 at the group's official website for the follow-up single to "Pretty Girl", which ended on February 2.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: By the deadline of February 2, "Honey" was the clear winner, with 60% of the votes.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The song was remixed from the original version, and also underwent a slight name change from "하니" (Ha-ni) to "Honey".
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The group released the music video for "Honey" on February 16 and had their first live broadcasting comeback on KBS's Music Bank program on February 13, 2009; a repackaged mini-album entitled Honey followed on February 19 which featured remixed versions of songs from the group's previous EP.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: "Honey" became the group's first number one single when it topped Gaon's weekly singles chart.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The song earned the group their first music show award on M!
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Countdown on March 5.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: It held onto the position for three nonconsecutive weeks.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The song also won the Mutizen award on SBS's program Inkigayo and the "Best Dance Award" at the 2009 Mnet Asian Music Awards.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: At the end of March, the group was chosen for the fourth season of MBC's Idol Show, which marked the group's first hosting duties for a show.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The group then had a reality show called MTV Meta Friends, which chronicled a group of fans getting a chance to become friends with the group members.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: For the show, the group had their first concert since their debut in 2007.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: In June 2009, the group stated they would make their comeback in late July, with their concept upgraded.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The first teaser pictures of the group were then released in mid-July, showing radical changes in the group's style and also saw a slight return of their "strong and mature" image previously seen from their debut.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Their single "Wanna" was released on July 28, 2009, and immediately charted on various digital music charts.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The music video was released on July 29, with the full album, Revolution, available online on July 30.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Comeback activities commenced on July 31, beginning with KBS's Music Bank; the group performed both "Wanna" and "Mister".
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: "Mister" proved to be popular with netizens due to the "butt dance" that is featured prominently in the choreography.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Due to the popularity of "Mister", Kara's overall popularity increased, evidenced by an influx of advertisement requests by various companies; in total, they had more advertisements in October 2009 than they had had the previous two years.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: "Wanna" also became a number one single for the group and won the Mutizen award on August 30, 2009, from Inkigayo.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: During promotions for Revolution, the group also performed internationally, including at Bangkok's Parc Paragon.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: On November 25, 2009, M. Net premiered the reality show called Kara Bakery, which followed the group as they attempted to plan, open, and advertise their own bakery.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: The show had 8 episodes and ran until early 2010.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: All proceeds from the bakery was donated to charity.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: On December 14, 2009, it was reported that the group held a fan-meeting for their Japanese fans earlier that year in February marking the group's first promotional tour in Japan.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

sentences: Over 3,000 fans were reportedly registered, exceeding the capacity of the venue which resulted in a second showcase.
section: == History == | === 2009: Rise in popularity in South Korea, Honey and Revolution ===

section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The photos garnered a lot of interest because compared to their past album concepts, the new photos showed the members in dark outfits and smokey makeup that elicited a darker, more mature, and sexier feel.

sentences: The next day, the album jacket was unveiled with a "Stealer" concept as well as the title track named "Lupin", which became number one on several online music charts shortly after release.

sentences: The teaser video was released on February 12 on Naver; the EP, Lupin, followed on February 17.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The music video was released on February 22, garnering more than 90,000 views in the first 2 hours.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The group began their broadcasting comeback starting on M!
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: On March 4, 2010, the group won their first number one award for "Lupin" on M! Countdown.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: On the following week, the group won yet another award on M! Countdown, making it their second consecutive win on the music program.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: "Lupin" also gave the group their first number one win on Music Bank on March 12, 2010, making it the group's first win on this particular music show since their debut, holding onto the position for three consecutive weeks.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The song also won the Mutizen award from Inkigayo on March 14.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: In March 2010, it was announced that the group will participate in the 8th Annual Korean Music Festival to be held at Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles, with member Jung Nicole as host.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: Afterwards, the group became very active in Japan, holding showcases and hand shake events as preparation for their official Japanese debut.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The group was featured in a video message for a show called Arashi no Shukudai-kun, hosted by Japanese idol group Arashi.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The group then held fan meetings on May 8 with more than 8,000 fans at Japan's Grand Prince Hotel.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: In addition, the group had an official Japan fan club meeting with 3,000 fans at Yokohama's Minato Mirai Hall on May 9.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The group later on signed with Universal Music Japan's subsidiary label, Universal Sigma.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: On August 11, the group released their debut single, the Japanese remake of their Korean song, "Mister".
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The single ranked in various music charts and proved to be very popular in Japan.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: Following the release, the single exceeded expectations as it charted at number five on Oricon's Daily Singles Chart with debut sales of 29,238 copies.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The song eventually became the most downloaded song of all time by a Korean artist in Japan, with downloads exceeding 2 million as of March 2012.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The group later on released their second single entitled "Jumping" on November 10, 2010.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The song quickly climbed up on many charts including mobile downloads, and debuted at number 5 on the Daily Singles Chart of Oricon.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: It eventually rose to number 2, only behind Arashi.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The single peaked at number 5 on Oricon's Weekly Singles Chart with debut sales of 54,977.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: On September 29, 2010, the group released their compilation album, Kara Best 2007-2010.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: The album is a compilation of their selected Korean tracks.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: It ranked number two on the Oricon Daily Albums Chart on the first day of release, selling 18,223 copies.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: It was announced on November 3, 2010, that the album was certified gold by the RIAJ, making the group the first ever Korean group since the 1990s to release an all-Korean album that was able break the 100 thousand copies barrier in Japan.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: It was eventually certified platinum with shipments exceeding 250,000 copies.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: On October 23, 2010, the band represented Korea and performed at the 7th annual Asia Song Festival, organized by Korea Foundation for International Culture Exchange, at the Seoul Olympic Stadium.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: Their debut Japanese album, Girl's Talk, was released on November 24, 2010.
section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: It sold 107,000 copies in its first week and ranked number 2 in the Oricon Weekly Album Chart, making this the first album by a non-Japanese girl group in Japan in 6 years and 9 months to sell more than 100,000 albums in its first week.

section: == History == | === 2010: Lupin, Japanese debut, and Girl's Talk ===

sentences: After taking a nine-month hiatus in the Korean music industry, the group announced the release of their single "Jumping", which was then promoted in both Korea and Japan.

sentences: It was released as the title track for their fourth Korean mini-album of the same name, Jumping.

sentences: Solo activities ===
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: On January 16, 2012, it was announced that the members of the group will each release their own solo material for their concerts in February.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: Park Gyuri's song entitled "Daydream", Han Seung-yeon's song entitled "Guilty", Jung Nicole's song entitled "Lost" featuring 2AM's Jinwoon, Goo Ha-ra's song entitled "Secret Love", and Kang Jiyoung's song entitled "Wanna Do" were all performed during their Karasia tour.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: All the songs were released one by one from August 22 to 26.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: The teasers for all the videos were released on August 31, 2012.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: The music videos for "Daydream" and "Secret Love" were released on September 1, 2012.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: The music videos for "Lost" and "Wanna Do" were released on September 3, 2012.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: The next day, the music video for "Guilty" was released.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===

sentences: The songs were included in their compilation album entitled Kara Collection.
section: == Other ventures == | === Solo activities ===
== Controversy ==

sentences: Controversy ==
section: == Controversy ==
== Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Request for contract termination =
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===
== Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: On January 19, 2011, a lawyer representing four of the five Kara members announced to the media that they would be terminating their contract with DSP Entertainment, effective immediately; a lawsuit was also filed on their behalf.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Park Gyuri, the leader of the group, was the only one remaining with their management company.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: In one statement, the lawyer representing the four stated that "the company repeatedly denied any requests and unilaterally forced tasks upon the members", and that they have been preparing for legal action for two months.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Later that day, it was announced that Goo Hara would discontinue her involvement with the lawsuit and has rejoined the company, as she apparently was not fully aware of the lawsuit's details.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: In a statement, DSP Entertainment firmly rebutted all accusations, also stating that they wished to resolve the issues and reconcile with the members quickly.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: DSP also denied earlier reports of denying Kara members their fair share of profits, stating that each member was paid ₩300,000,000 for their work.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: The lawyer for the three remaining members released another statement giving further details of their allegations.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Their representatives stated that they were misinformed regarding their Japanese promotions, and that their relationship with the company severely deteriorated with the hospitalization of CEO Lee Ho-yeon in March 2010.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: On April 28, 2011, the dispute between DSP Entertainment and Kara's 3 members (Han Seung-yeon, Nicole Jung, Kang Ji-young) was finally resolved.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: But two years later, in October 2013, DSP released statement that Nicole would not be renewing her contract with DSP Media upon its termination in January 2014.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Seungyeon, Gyuri and Hara all renewed their contracts for a further two years, and Jiyoung is taking her time to decide whether or not to study abroad, as her contract doesn't end until April 2014.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: However, it was confirmed later on by Nicole through her Twitter account that they are still in the midst of discussing and resolving the contract issues as Nicole still wants to work as a member of KARA while managed by a different agency.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Alongside Nicole's contract issue, DSP Media however has revealed that "Because Kang Ji Young contract expires in April next year, she has decided to think over her future."
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: An exclusive report from news outlet OSEN however had shed a bit more light regarding her circumstances with the news outlet claiming that Kang Ji Young was leaning towards making a decision to go abroad to study.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: The report claimed that while she wasn't outright saying that she wanted to leave the group, she had stated that she needed a certain amount of time to rest.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: On January 14, Jiyoung had officially made her decision to leave Kara once her contract expires in April 2014.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===

sentences: Jiyoung's father stated that it will be difficult, but is necessary for Jiyoung so she may leave DSP to pursue her dreams.
section: == Controversy == | === Request for contract termination ===
